title: Book Cover, André Gide by Van Meter Ames, 1940s
title_raw: André Gide by Van Meter Ames
medium: Offset lithograph on cream coated paper
signed: Imprinted in white, lower left corner:  lustig
inscribed: Imprinted in white to the right of center (sideways):  THE MAKERS OF MODERN LITERATURE; in black, center left:  andré/GIDE/by Van Meter Ames; along spine (sideways):  ANDRÉ GIDE by Van Meter Ames; in white, lower left corner: lustig
provenance: Susan Lustig Peck; 2001: acquired by Museum
description: A pie-shaped turquoise form fills the upper right corner; an irregular turquoise rectangle, whose top edge slopes upward, covers the lower half and lower spine. Joining the two turquoise forms, an over-printed large double arrow in black with two black circles (like tuning knobs on a musical instrument) on either side of the vertical stem.  Imprinted in white over the arrow (sideways):  THE MAKERS OF MODERN LITERATURE.   In the negative white area (between the turquoise forms), left, the book's title and author in black.  Along the spine (sideways), the book's title and author.
gallery_text: Borrowing from abstract painters, this book cover from the 1940s combines color, shape, and text in an unconventional way.  By employing a suggestive, rather than literal or illustrative, approach to graphic design, prominent American graphic, typeface, and book designer Alvin Lustig creates a sophisticated relationship between concept and physical form. The cover image does not directly depict what the book is about, but rather references it obliquely. Lustig reads the text to get a feel for the work and the author’s style, and then restates its central idea graphically.
